I’ve got a chip on my shoulder that’s bigger than my feet
A chip on your shoulder means being angry or sad, considering that his chip as big as his feet means that’s a pretty big ass chip

If I could see you now
 I’d try to make you sad somehow
 But I can’t so I’ll cry instead

A toned-down version of the need for reprisal in the first verse, but nonetheless still pusillanimous in the highest degree. John is steeped in hatred and he wants revenge and satisfaction… unfortunately he knows all he can do is cry it out… and maybe write a song about it.

I’ve got every reason on earth to be mad
 Cause I’ve just lost the only girl I had

It’s strange, for how emotionally charged the lyrics are John Lennon didn’t think too much of this song

I wrote that for A Hard Day’s Night, but Dick Lester didn’t even want it. He resurrected Can’t Buy Me Love for that sequence instead. I like the middle eight to that song, though – that’s about all I can say about it.

It may be because it was cut from the movie and replaced with “Can’t Buy Me Love”
It’s these types of songs which reveal the bands vulnerable side that allowed them to wiggle their way into the hearts of millions.

And when I do you better hide all the girls
 I’m gonna break their hearts all ’round the world
 Yes, I’m gonna break ’em in two

These lines show a lot of anger towards women. For as much love as John had inside of him, like any other human, he was also plagued by insecurities and memories of bad experiences. Other songs with misogyny and/or paranoia towards women include: “You Can’t Do That”, “Run For Your Life”, “Getting Better”, and “I’ll Get You”

These are rare instances though, and for the most part the band did nothing but praise the feminine spirit.
